subject: How do you test your Java EE 5 applications?
msgSnippet: = How do you test Java EE 5 applications = I ve researched several JUnit extensions without finding any I like. How do you test your EJB components? = One
messageBody:
= How do you test Java EE 5 applications =

I've researched several JUnit extensions without finding any I like.
How do you test your EJB components?

= One possible approach without any JUnit extension =

One approach I've heard is to have the session beans as dumb forwarders
of requests to normal objects. And implement the actual business logic
in normal Java classes. That way you're able to unit test your business
logic using a normal JUnit approach. What do you think of this approach?
And do you have any sources with more information about it? What if
there are instances of EJB stuff created inside the class? (Do we need
JMock?

One example of this approach:

// I guess a common interface is something you would want
ProcessShoppingInterface {
int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo);
}

// The normal class, doing some (imaginary) business logic in the
methoA method
// we can easily test this class using a normal JUnit test
ProcessShoppingCartClass extends ProcessShoppingInterface {
int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo) {
int tmp = inputOne;
for (int i=0 ; i < 99 ; i++) {
tmp += inputTwo/i;
if (tmp > 1000)
return tmp;
}
return tmp * 2;
}
}

// This is the session bean which simply forward calls to an instance
of the
// class where the actual logic resides
ProcessShoppingCartStatelessSessionBean extends
ProcessShoppingInterface {'
ProcessShoppingCart normal = new ProcessShoppingCart();
int methodA(int inputOne, int inputTwo) {
return normal.methodA(inputOne, inputTwo);
}
}

= Ejb3Unit =
I have tried this a bit. But it's pretty hard to get started as the
introductory material are sparse and doesn't give explanations about why
certain things are used, and which alternatives we had. It might be a
great framework for testing, however I am having a hard time with it as
I would have needed more documentation and tutorials.

Have you tried it? What do you think, is it worth the hassle? Have you
got any tips on how to get started with it?
